calendars.name: Islamic
calendars.leap_year_rules: The Islamic calendar is a lunar calendar, so leap years do not have a fixed pattern.

calendars.name: Hebrew
calendars.leap_year_rules: Leap years occur in a 19-year cycle, with certain years having an additional month called Adar II.

calendars.name: Hindu
calendars.leap_year_rules: Leap years are determined based on specific astronomical positions, with no fixed pattern like the Gregorian calendar.

calendars.name: Gregorian
calendars.leap_year_rules: A year is a leap year if it is divisible by 4, except for years that are divisible by 100 but not by 400.

calendars.name: International Fixed
calendars.leap_year_rules: There are no leap years in the Fixed International calendar, as each month has a fixed duration of 28 days and the year does not adjust based on solar or lunar movements.

calendars.name: Positivist
calendars.leap_year_rules: There are no leap years in the Positivist calendar, as each month has a fixed duration of 28 days and the year does not adjust based on solar or lunar movements.

calendars.name: Revolutionary
calendars.leap_year_rules: There are no leap years in the French Revolutionary calendar. Each month has a fixed duration of 30 days and adjusts based on solar movements.

calendars.name: Chinese
calendars.leap_year_rules: Leap years are determined by complex rules, typically adding an intercalary month (month 13) approximately every three years.
